As we look throughout the Word of God, there's really not a Bible character that we would refer to as being some type of a hero of the faith, someone that their life is worth studying and emulating, but that did not have problems. And this evening, as we think about our journey, listen, there are some that paint the idea of a Christian life being a bed of roses and just trust Jesus and all your problems are gonna go away. No, no, you trust Jesus and he's with you through all of your problems. Isn't that precious? I understand that man desires for all of his troubles to go away. But we live in a sin-cursed world, right? Jacob, the very first experience after he leaves the place where he met the Lord there in Bethel and after he'd made the vows and the commitments and after he gets to Haran and he meets Rachel and he meets Laban and all that takes place, seven years, he's deceived and it's a great level of deception. They're trials and difficulties that we face in life. Someone that said that the trust Christ and they've explained and tried to paint the picture that the Christian life is like a bed of roses, the reality is that knowing, think about this truth. All men have problems. All mankind has problems, right? Have you ever thought in your life this thought, I don't know how they do it without Christ? You've had that thought, have you not? You see people that suffer, you see people that struggle, you see people that deal with adversity, but so do we, but we have Christ. We have the Lord with us and he sustains us and he helps us and he guides us and he has purposes and he's growing us and he's molding us and listen, sometimes the molding process isn't very comfortable. Sometimes he uses some things like using that phrase firstborn where it's a flood of memories that must come back in the heart of Jacob and the mind of Jacob of all that he did to Esau and how he deceived Esau and all that took place and all that transpired and no doubt there would be some recollection of those things and God will use those types of things in our lives to conform us to the image of his dear son and I find that in the life of Jacob as we chronicle his journeys, as we chronicle his life and we trace his steps, that there are definitely some parallels for us. This evening, it is a joy to walk and talk with the king. It is an absolute joy to know the Lord Jesus Christ as our personal savior but our problems don't go away overnight but we have the Lord to help us through our problems. Listen, it's interesting that even though Jacob doesn't pray, in fact, it's a while before Jacob really prays and seeks the face of God, there's a lot of things that take place. We're at 14 years right now. The end of chapter number, well, we're at seven years and a week and then he's gonna serve for seven more years and by the end of the chapter, you're gonna be near 14 years because he's going to say, I'm ready to depart. So he's fulfilled that other seven years by the end of the chapter and still there's no record of Jacob praying at that point but you know what's interesting? God continued to bless Jacob. Laban recognized the blessing that God had put in his life because of Jacob. God always fulfills His promises. And God promised that He would be with Jacob and He would bless Jacob. And He did. And what a blessing that is. This evening, we're all at a different place of our journey with the Lord. But wherever you are, wherever I am in our journey with the Lord, I would say this, there are a number of interactions that we're going to have with all kinds of people. We're going to have various experiences, some that are less than desirable. We're going to be hurt. We're going to be deceived. But through it, on our journey, God is molding us and shaping us and helping us to be who we're supposed to be in Christ. Remember that song, He's Still Working on Me? See, He created all of the universe in just six days, right? Powerful. But see, He's still working on me, and He's still working on you. And by the way, we ought to be thankful that He's working on us, amen? And He's, in only the way that He can, as the potter with the clay, He's shaping us. And sometimes there's some rough edges that have to be taken care of, and God has His ways of taking care of those things. And so as we journey with the Lord, help us to keep our eyes on the Lord. Father, we love You. We thank You for loving us. Thank You for the day. Thank You for the blessings. As we think about the life of Jacob, we chronicle his life, we trace his steps, we see the events. I hope tonight that we could take, by way of application, some of this parallel of our own journey with You, that we'd learn some things not to do, and we'd learn some things to do. God, that You'd help us to seek Your face, that You'd help us to obey You. Such a blessing to have the whole canon of Scripture. And Lord, I pray that You'd be pleased with our lives, that we'd walk worthy as the believers in Ephesus are challenged to do so. I pray that You'd move and work in these moments of invitation as only You can, and we'll thank You for it. In Christ's name we pray.
